rename.from: Android requries new "FileProvider" means of accessing external files
rename.to: [Android] Android requries new "FileProvider" means of accessing external files

body:
FileProvider is used to share files from your app to other apps. FileHandle.External should work fine to access files on the SDCard, but you may have to request the `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission.

What type of file are you trying to load?

Edit: Looks like you've tried this, but it looks like aren't doing it correctly.
You should be using ActivityCompat to handle various version requirements, leave the xml permission for legacy users, and implement a callback to confirm permission. [requestPermissions is not blocking](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/app/ActivityCompat.html#requestPermissions\(android.app.Activity,%20java.lang.String[],%20int\)).

https://developer.android.com/training/permissions/requesting#make-the-request

> What type of file are you trying to load?

[Voxel models](https://github.com/ephtracy/voxel-model/blob/master/MagicaVoxel-file-format-vox-extension.txt).

I'll try what you said, but I think the docs that I linked contradict what you're saying. I could be wrong though, being new to this.

The issue you describe doesn't seem to be related to libGDX except from the fact that the wiki could be updated to explain how to deal with external files on Android. 
If you believe it is, please provide a SSCCE that reproduces the bug.
I'd also recommend taking a look at https://github.com/hedzr/android-file-chooser

As noted, FileProvider is for providing files, and should not be involved in reading the external storage. That said, using an intent to let another app find files for you will require you to play the content uri game.
How to turn a content: URI into a LibGDX FileHandle?

The easiest way is to use a ContentResolver to open an input stream, and copy to a file that you control - since you may not have perpetual access to the "file" they chose. Then just use that file for the handle.

I put file in quotes above because (like FileHandle itself) a content uri can refer to any content which may or may not actually be a file.
Is this related to deprecation of `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` and `WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permissions in Android Q?
Requesting this to be closed as it seems to be unrelated to LibGDX.

It's even more easy. On Android (and iOS), you should completely skip accessing external files. Most games are interested in importing and exporting data, and this can be achieved by the Storage Access Framework on Android and UIDocumentPicker on iOS. Both return (in case of import) an InputStream to work with. Easy, and no need to add scary permissions and tinker with runtime permissions.

I don't think we need to provide "FileProvider" support. That said, the general topic is still valid. Starting with Android 10, `FileType.External` is not working anymore on Android. I propose we change the `AndroidFile`'s `sdcard `path from:

> sdcard = Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory().getAbsolutePath() + "/";

to:

> sdcard = context.getExternalFilesDir(null) + "/";

`context` is the Android context. Probably the `sdcard `path can be passed into `AndroidFiles `while it is being constructed.

This isn't the best solution. However, the old path does NOT work at all. At least for the new path, the file access works and the data is on the SD card, albeit private to the app.

References:
https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage/files/external
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Context.html#getExternalFilesDir(java.lang.String)

> This isn't the best solution.

I think it is the best solution actually. It achieves everything a game needs external storage for, with a one line change in the backend code and zero changes in games codes.

issue.title: Petition to reconsider recent change to Gdx.files.external
issue.body:
So I updated my Snapshot and found my app could no longer find files saved on the device, turns out because Gdx.files.external now points to a different location (on Android).

This commit (a73cfa012eec5a647bc52274c5557948bad67aa3)

I understand the reasoning, but I feel like with already-established apps like mine and many others, Gdx.files.external has been understood to point to the root of the external storage since, basically forever.

My app is very user-generated-files based and I have a /AppName/ folder on the root directory with subfolders and all that, filled with saved data from my users. My app taps into these folders in many different areas of the UI. Right now all of my calls to Gdx.files.external(projectsFolder) for example no longer find anything because since this latest Snapshot it's pointing elsewhere (now to the /data/ folder of the app).

**Which again I understand but, I feel like this should be made to be either a separate function at this point to avoid breaking existing apps or at least have some kind of setting to change desired behavior.** I'd like external to refer to external storage as it has before. Not to mention I have 2 apps that access and share the same /AppName/ folder and is of massive convenience for my Android users (iOS users not so much, as iOS cannot have this functionality - speaking of, the fact the /data/ is cleared when app is uninstalled is also a detriment to many of my Android users, again an issue only my iOS users were plagued with).

Any chance of making this optional behavior and/or reverting to old behavior for Gdx.files.external? I see the reason for this commit was to fix issue #5633 but it seems as long as you request proper permissions and set up the FileProvider you're good - which seems reasonable?
